Embeddability of right-angled Artin groups on the complements of linear forests

Takuya Katayama (Takuya Katayama) Department of Mathematics, Hiroshima University, 1-3-1 Kagamiyama, Higashi-Hiroshima, Hiroshima 739-8526, Japan tkatayama@hiroshima-u.ac.jp
Abstract.

In this article, we prove that embeddings of right-angled Artin group A1subscriptğ´1A_{1} on the complement of a linear forest into another right-angled Artin group A2subscriptğ´2A_{2} can be reduced to full embeddings of the defining graph of A1subscriptğ´1A_{1} into the extension graph of the defining graph of A2subscriptğ´2A_{2}.

Key words and phrases:
Right-angled Artin group
2010 Mathematics Subject Classification:
Primary: 20F36

1. Introduction

Let Î“Î“\Gamma be a simple graph (abbreviated a graph). We denote the vertex set and the edge set of Î“Î“\Gamma by Vâ€‹(Î“)ğ‘‰Î“V(\Gamma) and Eâ€‹(Î“)ğ¸Î“E(\Gamma), respectively. The right-angled Artin group on Î“Î“\Gamma is the group given by the following presentation:

Aâ€‹(Î“)=âŸ¨Vâ€‹(Î“)âˆ£viâ€‹vjâ€‹viâˆ’1â€‹vjâˆ’1=1â€‹ifâ€‹{vi,vj}âˆˆEâ€‹(Î“)âŸ©.ğ´Î“inner-productğ‘‰Î“subscriptğ‘£ğ‘–subscriptğ‘£ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘–1superscriptsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘—11ifsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘–subscriptğ‘£ğ‘—ğ¸Î“A(\Gamma)=\langle V(\Gamma)\mid\ v_{i}v_{j}v_{i}^{-1}v_{j}^{-1}=1\ \mbox{if}\ \{v_{i},v_{j}\}\in E(\Gamma)\ \rangle.

A graph homomorphism is a map between the vertex sets of two graphs, which maps adjacent vertices to adjacent vertices. An injective graph homomorphism (abbreviated an embedding) Î¹:Î›â†’Î“:ğœ„â†’Î›Î“\iota\colon\Lambda\rightarrow\Gamma is called full if Î¹ğœ„\iota maps non-adjacent vertices to non-adjacent vertices. If there is a full embedding Î¹:Î›â†’Î“:ğœ„â†’Î›Î“\iota\colon\Lambda\rightarrow\Gamma, then we denote by Î›â‰¤Î“Î›Î“\Lambda\leq\Gamma and Î›Î›\Lambda is called a full subgraph of Î“Î“\Gamma. For finite graphs Î›Î›\Lambda and Î“Î“\Gamma, it is well-known that Aâ€‹(Î›)ğ´Î›A(\Lambda) is isomorphic to Aâ€‹(Î“)ğ´Î“A(\Gamma) as a group if and only if Î›Î›\Lambda is isomorphic to Î“Î“\Gamma as a graph. Following S.Â Kim and T.Â Koberda [4], the extension graph Î“esuperscriptÎ“ğ‘’\Gamma^{e} of a finite graph Î“Î“\Gamma is the graph such that the vertex set of Î“esuperscriptÎ“ğ‘’\Gamma^{e} consists of the words in Aâ€‹(Î“)ğ´Î“A(\Gamma) that are conjugate to the vertices of Î“Î“\Gamma, and two vertices of Î“esuperscriptÎ“ğ‘’\Gamma^{e} are joined by an edge if and only if they are commutative as words in Aâ€‹(Î“)ğ´Î“A(\Gamma). A celebrated theorem due to Kimâ€“Koberda states that, if a finite graph Î›Î›\Lambda is a full subgraph of the extension graph Î“esuperscriptÎ“ğ‘’\Gamma^{e} of a finite graph Î“Î“\Gamma, then we have an injective homomorphism (abbreviated an embedding) Aâ€‹(Î›)â†ªAâ€‹(Î“)â†ªğ´Î›ğ´Î“A(\Lambda)\hookrightarrow A(\Gamma). In this article, a path graph Pnsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘›P_{n} on n(â‰¥1)annotatedğ‘›absent1n\ (\geq 1) vertices is the graph whose underlying space is homeomorphic to the origin {0}0\{0\} or unit interval [0,1]01[0,1] in the 111-dimensional Euclidean space. A linear forest is the disjoint union of finitely many path graphs. The complement Î›csuperscriptÎ›ğ‘\Lambda^{c} of a graph Î›Î›\Lambda is the graph consisting of the vertex set Vâ€‹(Î›c)=Vâ€‹(Î›)ğ‘‰superscriptÎ›ğ‘ğ‘‰Î›V(\Lambda^{c})=V(\Lambda) and the edge set Eâ€‹(Î›c)={{u,v}âˆ£u,vâˆˆVâ€‹(Î›),{u,v}âˆ‰Eâ€‹(Î›)}ğ¸superscriptÎ›ğ‘conditional-setğ‘¢ğ‘£formulae-sequenceğ‘¢ğ‘£ğ‘‰Î›ğ‘¢ğ‘£ğ¸Î›E(\Lambda^{c})=\{\{u,v\}\mid u,v\in V(\Lambda),\ \{u,v\}\notin E(\Lambda)\}.

In [3] the author â€œprovedâ€ the following theorem.

Theorem 1.1.

Let Î›Î›\Lambda be the complement of a linear forest and Î“Î“\Gamma a finite graph. If Aâ€‹(Î›)â†ªAâ€‹(Î“)â†ªğ´Î›ğ´Î“A(\Lambda)\hookrightarrow A(\Gamma), then Î›â‰¤Î“Î›Î“\Lambda\leq\Gamma.

We remark that Theorem 1.1 is equivalent to [3, Theorem 1.3(1)]. In the proof of [3, Theorem 1.3(1)], the author used the following â€œTheoremâ€ (see the second line of the proof of Theorem 3.6 in [3]).

Theorem 1.2 ([1, Theorem 3.14]).

Let Î›Î›\Lambda be the complement of a forest and Î“Î“\Gamma a finite graph. If Aâ€‹(Î›)â†ªAâ€‹(Î“)â†ªğ´Î›ğ´Î“A(\Lambda)\hookrightarrow A(\Gamma), then Î›â‰¤Î“eÎ›superscriptÎ“ğ‘’\Lambda\leq\Gamma^{e}.

However, E.Â Lee and S.Â Lee [5] pointed out that the above â€œTheoremâ€ is incorrect by giving a counter-example. Thus the authorâ€™s proof of Theorem 1.1 in [3] is not valid.

The purpose of this article is to give a complete proof of Theorem 1.1 by establishing the following theorem which shows that â€œTheorem 1.2â€ holds when Î›Î›\Lambda is the complement of a linear forest.

Theorem 1.3.

Let Î›Î›\Lambda be the complement of a linear forest and Î“Î“\Gamma a finite graph. If Aâ€‹(Î›)â†ªAâ€‹(Î“)â†ªğ´Î›ğ´Î“A(\Lambda)\hookrightarrow A(\Gamma), then Î›â‰¤Î“eÎ›superscriptÎ“ğ‘’\Lambda\leq\Gamma^{e}.

In fact, the author applied â€œTheorem 1.2â€ only for the complement of linear forests in the proof of Theorem 1.3(1) in [3].

We note that this theorem gives a partial positive answer to the following question.

Question 1.4 ([4, Question 1.5]).

For which graphs Î›Î›\Lambda and Î“Î“\Gamma do we have Aâ€‹(Î›)â†ªAâ€‹(Î“)â†ªğ´Î›ğ´Î“A(\Lambda)\hookrightarrow A(\Gamma) only if Î›â‰¤Î“eÎ›superscriptÎ“ğ‘’\Lambda\leq\Gamma^{e}?

With regard to this question, the reader is referred to the introduction of the paper [5, Question 1.5] due to Leeâ€“Lee.

This article is organized as follows. In Section 2, we introduce terminology and known results. For the sake of convenience, we discuss relation between graph-join (a certain graph operation) and embedding problems in Section 3. Section 4 is devoted to the proof of Theorem 1.3.

2. Preliminaries

Suppose that Î“Î“\Gamma is a graph. An element of Vâ€‹(Î“)âˆªVâ€‹(Î“)âˆ’1ğ‘‰Î“ğ‘‰superscriptÎ“1V(\Gamma)\cup V(\Gamma)^{-1} is called a letter. Any element in Aâ€‹(Î“)ğ´Î“A(\Gamma) can be expressed as a word, which is a finite multiplication of letters. Let w=a1â€‹â‹¯â€‹alğ‘¤subscriptğ‘1â‹¯subscriptğ‘ğ‘™w=a_{1}\cdots a_{l} be a word in Aâ€‹(Î“)ğ´Î“A(\Gamma) where a1,â€¦,alsubscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘™a_{1},\ldots,a_{l} are letters. We say wğ‘¤w is reduced if any other word representing the same element as wğ‘¤w in Aâ€‹(Î“)ğ´Î“A(\Gamma) has at least lğ‘™l letters. The following lemma is useful for checking whether a given word is reduced or not (cf. [2, Section 5]).

Lemma 2.1.

Let wğ‘¤w be a word in Aâ€‹(Î“)ğ´Î“A(\Gamma). Then wğ‘¤w is reduced if and only if wğ‘¤w does not contain a word of the form vÏµâ€‹xâ€‹vâˆ’Ïµsuperscriptğ‘£italic-Ïµğ‘¥superscriptğ‘£italic-Ïµv^{\epsilon}xv^{-\epsilon}, where vğ‘£v is a vertex of Î“Î“\Gamma, Ïµ=Â±1italic-Ïµplus-or-minus1\epsilon=\pm 1 and xğ‘¥x is a word such that vğ‘£v is commutative with all of the letters in xğ‘¥x.

The support of a reduced word wğ‘¤w is the smallest subset Sğ‘†S of Vâ€‹(Î“)ğ‘‰Î“V(\Gamma) such that each letter of wğ‘¤w is in Sğ‘†S or Sâˆ’1superscriptğ‘†1S^{-1}; we write S=suppâ€‹(w)ğ‘†suppğ‘¤S=\mathrm{supp}(w). It is well-known that the support does not depend on the choice of a reduced word, and so we can define the support of an element of Aâ€‹(Î“)ğ´Î“A(\Gamma). By a clique, we mean a complete subgraph of a graph. We rephrase a special case of Servatiusâ€™ Centralizer Theorem [6, The Centralizer Theorem in Section III] as follows.

Lemma 2.2.

Let w1subscriptğ‘¤1w_{1} and w2subscriptğ‘¤2w_{2} be reduced words in Aâ€‹(Î“)ğ´Î“A(\Gamma) whose supports span cliques in Î“Î“\Gamma. Then the words w1subscriptğ‘¤1w_{1} and w2subscriptğ‘¤2w_{2} are commutative if and only if suppâ€‹(w1)suppsubscriptğ‘¤1\mathrm{supp}(w_{1}) and suppâ€‹(w2)suppsubscriptğ‘¤2\mathrm{supp}(w_{2}) are contained in a single clique in Î“Î“\Gamma.

In this article, we say that a homomorphism Ïˆ:Aâ€‹(Î›)â†’Aâ€‹(Î“):ğœ“â†’ğ´Î›ğ´Î“\psi\colon A(\Lambda)\rightarrow A(\Gamma) between two right-angled Artin groups satisfies (KK) condition if suppâ€‹(Ïˆâ€‹(v))suppğœ“ğ‘£\mathrm{supp}(\psi(v)) consists of mutually adjacent vertices in Î“Î“\Gamma for all vâˆˆVâ€‹(Î›)ğ‘£ğ‘‰Î›v\in V(\Lambda) (i.e., suppâ€‹(Ïˆâ€‹(v))suppğœ“ğ‘£\mathrm{supp}(\psi(v)) spans a clique in Î“Î“\Gamma).

Theorem 2.3 ([4, Theorem 4.3]).

Suppose that Î›Î›\Lambda and Î“Î“\Gamma are finite graphs and Aâ€‹(Î›)â†ªAâ€‹(Î“)â†ªğ´Î›ğ´Î“A(\Lambda)\hookrightarrow A(\Gamma). Then there is an embedding Ïˆ:Aâ€‹(Î›)â†ªAâ€‹(Î“e):ğœ“â†ªğ´Î›ğ´superscriptÎ“ğ‘’\psi\colon A(\Lambda)\hookrightarrow A(\Gamma^{e}) such that Ïˆğœ“\psi satisfies (KK) condition. Namely, for all vâˆˆVâ€‹(Î›)ğ‘£ğ‘‰Î›v\in V(\Lambda), suppâ€‹(Ïˆâ€‹(v))suppğœ“ğ‘£\mathrm{supp}(\psi(v)) consists of mutually adjacent vertices in Î“esuperscriptÎ“ğ‘’\Gamma^{e}.

3. Graph-join

The (graph-)join Î›1âˆ—â‹¯âˆ—Î›msubscriptÎ›1â‹¯subscriptÎ›ğ‘š\Lambda_{1}*\cdots*\Lambda_{m} of graphs Î›1,â€¦,Î›msubscriptÎ›1â€¦subscriptÎ›ğ‘š\Lambda_{1},\ldots,\Lambda_{m} is the graph obtained from the disjoint union Î›1âŠ”â‹¯âŠ”Î›msquare-unionsubscriptÎ›1â‹¯subscriptÎ›ğ‘š\Lambda_{1}\sqcup\cdots\sqcup\Lambda_{m} by joining the vertices uğ‘¢u and vğ‘£v for all uâˆˆVâ€‹(Î›i),vâˆˆVâ€‹(Î›j)formulae-sequenceğ‘¢ğ‘‰subscriptÎ›ğ‘–ğ‘£ğ‘‰subscriptÎ›ğ‘—u\in V(\Lambda_{i}),v\in V(\Lambda_{j}) (iâ‰ jğ‘–ğ‘—i\neq j). In this article, we say that a graph Î›Î›\Lambda is irreducible (with respect to join) if Î›Î›\Lambda cannot be the join of two non-empty graphs. Any finite graph Î›Î›\Lambda is the join of finitely many irreducible graphs. Indeed, this follows from the fact that Î›=Î›1âˆ—â‹¯âˆ—Î›mÎ›subscriptÎ›1â‹¯subscriptÎ›ğ‘š\Lambda=\Lambda_{1}*\cdots*\Lambda_{m} if and only if Î›c=Î›1câŠ”â‹¯âŠ”Î›mcsuperscriptÎ›ğ‘square-unionsuperscriptsubscriptÎ›1ğ‘â‹¯superscriptsubscriptÎ›ğ‘šğ‘\Lambda^{c}=\Lambda_{1}^{c}\sqcup\cdots\sqcup\Lambda_{m}^{c}. This fact also implies the following lemma.

Lemma 3.1.

A finite graph Î›Î›\Lambda is irreducible if and only if Î›csuperscriptÎ›ğ‘\Lambda^{c} is connected. In particular, if Î›Î›\Lambda is an irreducible graph containing at least two vertices, then for any vertex uâˆˆVâ€‹(Î›)ğ‘¢ğ‘‰Î›u\in V(\Lambda), there is a vertex uâ€²âˆˆVâ€‹(Î›)superscriptğ‘¢â€²ğ‘‰Î›u^{\prime}\in V(\Lambda) such that uğ‘¢u and uâ€²superscriptğ‘¢â€²u^{\prime} are non-adjacent.

Lemma 4.5 ([4, Theorem 5.4]).

Lemma 4.6.
